problem: If all A are B, and all B are C, must all A be C?

problem: In the Monty Hall problem, should you switch doors?
initial_answer: Yes — switching increases your chance of winning from 1/3 to 2/3.
final_answer: No — in the standard Monty Hall (Monty always opens a goat door and never the car) you should switch; switching wins with probability 2/3. The 50/50 claim is only true for a different variant where Monty opens a random other door and you condition on him having (by chance) revealed a goat.
initial_reasoning: Your initial pick has a 1/3 chance of the car. Monty then opens a goat door; if your initial pick was wrong (2/3 chance) the other unopened door must have the car, so switching wins with probability 2/3.
final_reasoning: With three doors your initial pick has probability 1/3 of being the car. If Monty always avoids the car and opens a goat, the 2/3 probability that you were wrong concentrates on the one remaining closed door, so switching wins 2/3. If instead Monty picked a door uniformly at random and you only consider cases where he happened to reveal a goat, the conditional probability your original pick is correct becomes 1/2, so switching makes no difference in that specific variant.

problem: In the Monty Hall problem, should you switch doors?
initial_answer: Yes — switching gives a 2/3 chance of winning (staying gives 1/3).

initial_reasoning: Your initial choice has a 1/3 chance of being the car. Monty, who knows where the car is, opens a goat door; switching wins whenever your initial pick was wrong, which is 2/3 of the time.

Only if the host opens a door at random or could reveal the car (i.e., different host rules) does the problem reduce to 50/50.

problem: In the Monty Hall problem, should you switch doors?
final_answer: It depends. In the standard Monty Hall (host knows the car and always opens a goat) you should switch — switching wins with probability 2/3. If the host opened one of the other doors uniformly at random and happened to reveal a goat (i.e. he had no knowledge), then conditional on that event switching is 1/2.
initial_reasoning: Your initial pick has a 1/3 chance of being the car. The host (who knows where the car is) opens a goat door among the other two. If your initial pick was wrong (2/3), switching gives the car; if it was right (1/3), switching loses. Thus switching wins 2/3 of the time.
final_reasoning: Standard case: your first pick has 1/3 chance of car, host's informed reveal transfers the remaining 2/3 to the other unopened door, so switching wins 2/3. In the random-host variant, P(initial car | host showed goat) = (1/3)/((1/3)+(2/3)*(1/2)) = 1/2, so it's 50/50.

problem: In the Monty Hall problem, should you switch doors?
initial_answer: Yes — switching doubles your chance of winning (2/3 vs 1/3).

The 50/50 claim only holds in a different variant where the host opens a random unchosen door and you condition on the event he happened to reveal a goat.

problem: Is 0.999... (0.9 repeating forever) equal to 1?
initial_reasoning: Let x = 0.999... then 10x = 9.999...; subtracting gives 9x = 9 so x = 1. Equivalently, 0.999... is the geometric series 0.9 + 0.09 + ... = 0.9/(1-0.1) = 1.
final_reasoning: By the standard definition of 0.999... as the limit of the finite sums 0.9, 0.99, 0.999,... we get the geometric series 0.9+0.09+... = 0.9/(1−0.1)=1. Algebraically, letting x=0.999..., 10x=9.999..., subtracting gives 9x=9 so x=1. Claims of a distinct number infinitesimally below 1 come from nonstandard constructions (hyperreal numbers) or alternative interpretations of a ‘‘decimal with a last 9 at an infinite position’’; those are not equalities in the standard real number system where 0.999... is exactly 1.

final_reasoning: By the usual (standard) definition 0.999... is the limit of the partial sums 0.9, 0.99, 0.999, ... which equals 1 (or algebraically: let x=0.999..., 10x=9.999..., subtract to get x=1). problem: If all A are B, and all B are C, must all A be C?
final_answer: No. The syllogism is valid (transitivity of inclusion).
initial_reasoning: If all A are B (A ⊆ B) and all B are C (B ⊆ C), then by transitivity A ⊆ C, so every A is C.
final_reasoning: If all A ⊆ B and all B ⊆ C, then by transitivity A ⊆ C, so every A is C. The fallacy of composition attributes properties of parts to a whole; this argument is about class inclusion, not attributing part-properties to a collective. Only ambiguity or a shift in term meaning would make it invalid.

problem: If all A are B, and all B are C, must all A be C?
final_answer: Yes — the argument is valid; it is not a fallacy of composition.
initial_reasoning: For any x, if x is A then x is B, and if x is B then x is C; therefore if x is A it must be C, so all A are C.
final_reasoning: From ∀x(A(x) → B(x)) and ∀x(B(x) → C(x)) we can deduce ∀x(A(x) → C(x)) by transitivity of implication. The fallacy of composition (inferring a whole has a property because its parts do) is a different error (e.g. every cell is microscopic, therefore the organism is microscopic). This syllogism (Aristotelian form Barbara) is valid.

problem: If all A are B, and all B are C, must all A be C?
final_answer: No — the syllogism is valid: if A⊆B and B⊆C then A⊆C.
initial_reasoning: If every A is a B and every B is a C, then any A is a B and therefore a C. Formally: from ∀x(A(x)→B(x)) and ∀x(B(x)→C(x)) infer ∀x(A(x)→C(x)).
final_reasoning: From ∀x(A(x)→B(x)) and ∀x(B(x)→C(x)) infer ∀x(A(x)→C(x)) by transitivity of implication/subset. The fallacy of composition concerns attributing a property of parts to the whole, which is a different error and does not apply to categorical inclusion.

problem: If all A are B, and all B are C, must all A be C?
initial_reasoning: From 'all A are B' and 'all B are C' we have A ⊆ B and B ⊆ C, so A ⊆ C. Equivalently, if x is A then x is B and hence x is C, so all A are C.
